item.title: Schools in Europe Reopen With Little Debate---but More Masks and Distancing
item.description: European countries are pushing ahead with reopening schools despite an uptick in coronavirus cases and new studies suggesting children could be more susceptible to the disease than originally thought.

item.title: Facebook's Hate-Speech Rules Collide With Indian Politics
item.description: A company executive in the vital market opposed a move to ban a controversial politician who staffers concluded had violated hate-speech rules. Some current and former employees allege the ruling party got favorable treatment.

item.title: Son of Former Angolan President Convicted in $500 Million Fraud
item.description: Angola’s Supreme Court sentenced four men, including the son of the former president and the former governor of the central bank, for embezzling $500 million from the country’s central bank in 2017.

item.title: Turkish, Greek Frigates Collide in the Mediterranean Sea
item.description: Rival warships from Turkey and Greece have collided in the Eastern Mediterranean, officials from both countries said, amid a naval standoff triggered by Ankara’s recent decision to begin oil exploration in contested waters.

item.title: Israel's Normalization With U.A.E. Squeezes Saudi Arabia
item.description: The surprise move of the United Arab Emirates to normalize ties with Israel piles pressure on Saudi Arabia to follow suit—at the risk of inflaming public sentiment and breaking from the monarchy’s track record of promoting the Palestinian cause.

item.title: China's Recovery Loses Some Momentum as Retail Sales Disappoint Again
item.description: Factories continued to lead the recovery, but retail sales remained in negative territory, defying expectations for a second straight month of a return to pre-coronavirus levels.
